questions.text: Physiological calcification is seen in all of the structures except:
questions.solution:
Physiologic calcification is not seen in the red nucleus.

The following image shows calcification in the pineal gland:

 

The image below shows heavily calcified falx:

Related Pearl: Sites of normal intracranial calcification

  • Pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure
  • Choroid plexus
  • The dura
  • Ligaments (petroclinoid and interclinoid)
  • Pacchionian bodies
  • Basal ganglia - physiological only in a senile person
  • Pituitary gland
  • Arachnoid granulations

NOTE: The lens (not intracranial) can also be seen as a calcified structure

questions.text: In which condition is popcorn calcification seen?
questions.solution:
Popcorn calcification is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.

Popcorn calcification is defined as a pattern of calcification in rings and arcs that resemble popped corn kernels. The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule that does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

Chest x-ray showing pulmonary hamartoma:

questions.text:
The IVP of a patient with persistent flank pain is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

IVP- Intravenous Pyelogram
questions.solution:
The given IVP in a patient with persistent flank pain shows the medial deviation of bilateral ureters, caused by fibrous tissue deposition in the retroperitoneum at the lumbosacral junction, resulting in the characteristic narrow-waisted maiden appearance, known as the maiden waist sign, which is seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is a chronic, nonspecific inflammatory process of the fibro-fatty tissue in the retroperitoneum, with the idiopathic type being the most common, accounting for about 70% of the cases. Patients typically present with persistent flank pain or back pain. Progressive fibrotic thickening can compress the ureters, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and, if untreated, renal failure. Aside from idiopathic causes, other causes of RPF include drug-induced factors ( e.g., methysergide, beta-blockers), advanced malignancy, radiation exposure, trauma, and chronic infections.

Diagnosis of RPF relies primarily on imaging studies. Intravenous urography shows a characteristic triad of medial deviation of the middle one-third of the ureters, producing a maiden waist sign, hydroureteronephrosis, and extrinsic compression of the ureters by the fibrotic process. CT and MRI are also useful in radiographic evaluation of RPF.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution:
Gamma rays show maximum penetration.

When a nucleus disintegrates, it will emit radiation either as photons (X or gamma rays) or as high-velocity particles. Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) similar to X-rays, however, distinguished from the latter by the fact that they are emitted from an excited nucleus. Gamma radiation is highly penetrating and interacts with matter through ionization via two processes, the photoelectric effect, and Compton scattering.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: A neonate is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities. Ultrasonography reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a dilated proximal urethra and associated thick-walled distended bladder on ultrasound that resembles a keyhole. This keyhole sign is seen in the presence of posterior urethral valves. 

Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children. The valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. 

Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder in the fetus, along with oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infections in the neonatal period or with uremia and renal failure. Clinically, a poor urinary stream, dribbling, and palpable bladder (due to diverticula) can be present.

The diagnosis is best made during the micturition phase of VCUG in lateral or oblique views so that the posterior urethra can be imaged adequately. The following findings are seen:

  • Dilatation and elongation of the posterior urethra - the equivalent of the ultrasonographic keyhole sign (as shown in the image below).
  • Linear radiolucent band corresponding to the valve - seen occasionally.
  • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) - seen in 50% of patients.
  • Bladder trabeculation/ diverticula.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic male presents with acute onset abdominal pain and vomiting. His last alcohol binge was yesterday night. A blood panel reveals elevated pancreatic lipase and amylase levels by almost threefold. Which of the following signs can be seen during radiological imaging?
questions.solution:
The case scenario provided above is highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All of the signs mentioned above can be seen in a case of acute pancreatitis.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as "A" in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as "A" in the CT Thorax is the Azygos vein.

questions.text: The image below is an axial CT scan of the upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a peritoneal neoplasia characterized by the accumulation of mucin-producing tumor cells in the peritoneal cavity and usually occurs following rupture of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the appendix. However, it may also occur due to the rupture of the tumors of ovary, pancreas, stomach, colorectal, or urachus.

Imaging findings:

  • Accumulation of mucinous material, which is seen as masses of low attenuation on CT and moderately high signal intensity on MRI.
  • Scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen.
  • The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a dry cough. A chest X-ray reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows a pattern of lymph node enlargement seen in sarcoidosis.

The characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement in this condition is called the Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. The lymph nodes involved are:

  1. Right paratracheal nodes
  2. Right hilar nodes
  3. Left hilar nodes

Image showing a pattern of lymph node enlargement (1-2-3 sign):

questions.text: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks, the pregnancy can be terminated. 

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but don't appear below it. This suggests a fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks.

Reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) suggests impending fetal death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign on MRI is seen in:
questions.solution:
An empty thecal sac sign is seen in arachnoiditis.

Adhesive arachnoiditis can be diagnosed if the empty thecal sac indication is observed. This occurs due to inflammation, which leads to clumping of nerve roots. This leads to an empty sac appearance. It is best observed on T2-weighted MRI scans of the lumbar spine when the thecal sac appears empty.

questions.text: The image seen below shows_______.
questions.solution:
The image given is of the findings seen in hysterosalpingography. The given image shows bilateral retort-shaped fallopian tubes, indicating bilateral hydrosalpinx. 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radioopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e. 9th or 10th day of the cycle). 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel. 

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block: This can be due to strictures (fibrotic block), inspissated amorphous material, or spasms. The tubal spasm can occur in an apprehensive woman, and this is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contradictions:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase (there is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase).

 The image given below shows the appearance of a normal hysterosalpingogram. 

Laparoscopic chromopertubation is a laparoscopic procedure for establishing the patency of fallopian tubes or verifying the findings of blocked tubes on HSG. Methylene blue is injected through the cervix to visualize the free spill. The absence of spill indicates blocked tubes.

questions.text: The cystographic evaluation of a woman with recurrent urinary tract infection is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cystogram shows an elongated and pointed bladder with a thickened trabeculated wall, called a Christmas tree or pine cone bladder. This is seen in patients with severe neurogenic bladder and increased sphincter tone.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination. It causes detrusor sphincter dyssynergia. Neurogenic bladder typically occurs due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or apical lesions (in and around S2-S4).

Pine cone bladder is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It may also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

Other options:

Option A: Tuberculous cystitis results in fibrosis and stiffening of the entire urinary bladder, leading to an inability to expand and a significant reduction in bladder capacity, as depicted in the image below. The medical term for this feature on micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is a thimble bladder. 

Option C: In bladder carcinoma, lesions are seen on the wall of the bladder and a biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. These lesions cause disruption in the mucosa and the musculature of the bladder. Cystourethroscopy is the mainstay for the diagnosis of bladder carcinoma. It is performed on patients with hematuria. The most common radiological sign is a filling defect seen in intravenous urography (IVU). 

Option D: Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma hematobium. The radiographic features in the acute phase is nodular bladder wall thickening, and in the chronic phase, it is the contracted fibrotic, thick-walled bladder and curvilinear calcifications due to large numbers of calcified eggs in the bladder wall. On cystoscopy, it can look like nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, and sandy patches, and in the end stage, it can cause squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

The CT-KUB image below shows circumferential calcification of the bladder wall.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents after a fall from her bicycle. She has no pain but could not get up due to weakness in her hands and legs. Cervical spine x-ray showed no fractures or loss of alignment. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given case of a child presenting with weakness after a fall but no abnormalities on radiological imaging indicates a diagnosis of Spinal Cord Injury Without Obvious Radiographic Abnormality (SCIWORA). MRI is the next best step in this case to identify nerve damage.

Related Pearl: SCIWORA

SCIWORA- Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality.

It is defined as a spinal cord injury in a patient with no visible fracture or dislocation on plain radiographs or CT scans.

It is almost completely unique to children. It is believed to occur because the vertebral column (vertebrae and disc space) in children is more elastic than the spinal cord. Hence, the vertebral column in children can undergo considerable deformation without being disrupted. The vertebral column in children can elongate up to 2 inches without disruption, whereas the spinal cord gets injured with only a quarter-inch of elongation.

X-ray/CT may not show vertebral injuries, but MRI shows evidence of spinal cord injury.

questions.text: Identify this congenital anomaly found on the MRI image of a neonate.
questions.solution:
The given axial T1 weighted image demonstrates the typical figure of eight sign consistent in a neonate with lissencephaly. This disorder results from defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14th weeks of gestation, leading to a poor development or absence of gyri and sulci, thickened cortex, and shallow, widened Sylvian fissures, contributing to the above radiographic appearance. Other associated anomalies may include agenesis or hypoplasia of the corpus callosum or septum pellucidum. 

The following image shows the figure of eight sign of lissencephaly:

Other options:

Option A: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and inadequate induction of forebrain structures. The pancake brain sign represents the appearance of the cerebral parenchyma in the case of alobar holoprosencephaly.

Option C: Schizencephaly is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres due to an abnormality of morphogenesis. 

Option D: Porencephaly is an extremely rare cephalic disorder involving encephalomalacia. It is a neurological disorder of the central nervous system characterized by cysts or cavities within the cerebral hemisphere.

questions.text: The empty delta sign is a radiological feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: The empty delta sign is a characteristic finding of superior sagittal sinus thrombosis, seen on contrast-enhanced CT(CECT) or MRI. It appears as a triangular filling defect(clot) outlined by contrast. This sign is not observed on non-contrast imaging.

questions.text: Antenatal USG in a primigravida revealed fetal hydrocephalus. Postnatal MRI of the infant is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given T2 MRI image shows the racing car appearance, which is seen in agenesis of the corpus callosum. This sign refers to the widely spaced lateral ventricles with intervening Probst bundles(white matter tracts that are no longer able to cross the midline in the corpus callosum).

Appearances on axial MRI or CT resemble a Formula One car seen from above. The front tyres are represented by the widely spaced frontal horns anteriorly. The back tyres are represented by the dilated trigones seen posteriorly, which is also known as colpocephaly.

The image given below shows the racing car sign in corpus callosal agensis.

Other options:

Option B: Marchiafava - Bignami disease is a rare condition characterized by demyelination of the corpus callosum most often in patients with chronic alcoholism. The MRI image in this condition shows the sandwich sign.

 

Option C: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal-recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A. Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2 hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent the sparing of the perivascular white matter. This results in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U-fibers are spared.

Option D: The most common site of lipoma in the brain is the peri-callosal region. The CT below shows bracket calcification of lipoma and is called bracket sign.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who was a welder for the past 10 years presents with a dry cough, easy fatiguability, weight loss, and dyspnea progressing over the past 1 year. On examination, fine end-inspiratory crackles were heard over the bilateral infra-axillary regions. His HRCT finding is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The HRCT provided shows a characteristic crazy-paving pattern which is classical of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. 

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a lung disease involving the accumulation of surfactant within the alveoli as a result of decreased clearance. It may be congenital, secondary, or autoimmune.

Etiology:

  • Congenital
  • Secondary: due to lung infections, hematologic malignancies, and inhalation of mineral dust such as silica, titanium oxide, aluminum, indium-tin-oxide, and insecticides.
  • Autoimmune: autoantibodies against GM-CSF

Patients may have features like a persistent dry cough (or with scant sputum production), progressive dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and/or night sweats, and pleuritic chest pain. Rarely, they may have cyanosis and hemoptysis. The physical examination will show fine end-inspiratory crackles. Clubbing and cyanosis may be present in a few cases.

Diagnosis is with bronchoscopic lavage and/or biopsy, along with imaging findings. Chest X-ray shows nonspecific findings with bilateral lung opacification. A batwing appearance may be seen.

The CT shows a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern. It refers to geographical areas of ground-glass opacification with thickened inter-and intralobular septa.

Treatment includes whole lung lavage and treatment of the underlying cause. GM-CSF replacement is considered if an underlying autoimmune etiology is suspected.

Other causes causing similar crazy-paving appearance:

  • Lipoid pneumonia
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
  • Silicosis,
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonian features which is unresponsive to levodopa. MRI image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly male with a history of features of Parkinsonism nonresponsive to levodopa should raise suspicion for Parkinson plus syndrome or Atypical parkinsonism. The given MRI showing the hummingbird sign is suggestive of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).

Progressive supranuclear palsy is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease that is characterised by an aggressive clinical course and early involvement of speech and gait, absence of rest tremors, decreased cognition, abnormal eye movements (supranuclear vertical gaze palsy), postural instability and falls, as well as Parkinsonian features and speech disturbances. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), also known as the Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, is a tauopathy and is considered a neurodegenerative disease with no current efficacious treatment. 

The atrophy of the midbrain results in hummingbird sign of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane). The preserved pons form the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain, the head, with beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasm. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with the reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio.

Mickey mouse appearance, which is the reduction of anteroposterior midline midbrain diameter, at the level of the superior colliculi is seen on axial imaging.

The following image shows the hummingbird sign:

questions.text: While reading the X-Ray of a 32-year-old female who has come for her annual health check,  you notice the unilateral elevation of the diaphragm. Which of the following conditions is it least likely to be?
questions.solution:
Poor inspiration would result in a bilaterally elevated diaphragm, not unilateral elevation.

Causes of Unilateral Elevation of the Diaphragm

 

  • Posture—lateral decubitus position (dependent side)
  • Gaseous distension of stomach or colon
  • Dorsal scoliosis
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary collapse
  • Phrenic nerve palsy
  • Eventration
  • Pneumonia or pleurisy
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism
  • Rib fracture and other painful conditions
  • Subphrenic infection
  • Subphrenic mass

 

Causes of Bilateral Symmetrical

Elevation of the Diaphragm

 

  • Supine position
  • Poor inspiration
  • Obesity
  • Pregnancy
  • Abdominal distension 
  • Diffuse pulmonary fibrosis
  • Lymphangitis carcinomatosa
  • Disseminated lupus erythematosus
  • Bilateral basal pulmonary emboli
  • Pain after abdominal surgery
  • Bilateral diaphragmatic paralysis

questions.text: Identify the artery marked by blue arrow.
questions.solution:
The artery marked by the blue arrow is the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which gives rise to various branches that supply the small intestines, cecum, ascending, and part of the transverse colon.

The CT also depicts nutcracker syndrome, a left renal vein entrapment syndrome characterized by extrinsic compression of the left renal vein (marked by a red arrow), most commonly between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery. This syndrome is one of the postulated reasons for left-sided varicoceles being more common than the right side.

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents the M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and a trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Ultrasonography is a versatile imaging modality known for its portability and safety, particularly as it does not involve radiation exposure. As the safest radiological investigation for pregnancy, it provides crucial information without posing any risks to the mother or fetus, making it indispensable in obstetric care. 

Different modes in USG and its uses are as follows:

  1. A (amplitude) mode: Used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry (option A).
  2. B (brightness) mode: Used for all routine applications, with brightness encoded as grayscale value (option B).
  3. M (motion) mode: In echocardiography. 

HIFU (high-intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered, tightly focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

The image below depicts a duplex scan, which is a combination of B-mode imaging and pulsed Doppler data acquisition.

Doppler ultrasound (option D) is used in diagnosing peripheral arterial disease. It uses a handheld Doppler ultrasound probe placed at an arterial site. A normal arterial wave has a triphasic signal. A triphasic wave has three waveforms consisting of a sharp systolic wave with a forward uprise and fall, a second wave with reverse flow occurring in diastole, and the last wave with a forward flow taking place during diastole. 

Doppler ultrasound can detect moving blood. However, it does not provide information on whether the blood flow is sufficient for the maintenance of limb viability. 

The image below shows triphasic signal on doppler ultrasound:

questions.text: An abdominal x-ray of a neonate admitted to NICU is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal x-ray of the neonate shows the double bubble sign, which is suggestive of duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum due to the failure of recanalisation during embryonic development from its solid cord stage, leaving the duodenum partially or completely obstructed. It is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system.

The range of anatomic variants includes duodenal stenosis, mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity), two ends separated by a fibrous cord, and complete separation with a gap within the duodenum. 

On abdominal X-ray, the double bubble sign represents the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This can often be detected prenatally via ultrasound but, if missed, neonates typically present with bilious vomiting shortly after birth, as the obstruction is usually distal to the ampulla of Vater. 

Causes of double bubble sign are congenital obstruction - duodenal atresia (associated with Down syndrome), midgut volvulus, and external compression of the duodenum.

The radiological finding obtained on the barium study is a windsock deformity.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A young man presented with weight loss, and recurrent episodes of non-bloody diarrhea for the past 6 months. CT abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT abdomen showing comb sign is suggestive of Crohn's disease.

The comb sign refers to the hypervascular appearance of the mesentery in active Crohn's disease. The fibrofatty proliferation and perivascular inflammatory infiltration outline the distended intestinal arcades. This forms linear densities on the mesenteric side of the affected segments of the small bowel, which give the appearance of the teeth of a comb.
