questions.text: A 20-year-old footballer sustained a sliding tackle during a match and fell on the ground in pain. An MRI was done and the double posterior cruciate ligament sign was noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and double posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) sign on MRI are suggestive of medial meniscal tear.

The sign appears on sagittal MRI images of the knee due to bucket-handle meniscal tears. The torn meniscus flips towards the centre of the joint and hence lies anteroinferior to the PCL, mimicking a second smaller PCL.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess, as the chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level. Clindamycin is the drug of choice for treating lung abscesses.

Chest X-ray showing lung abscess(yellow) with air-fluid level (arrow):

Clindamycin is preferred over penicillin for primary lung abscesses (caused by aspirating oral flora in healthy individuals) due to its effectiveness against β-lactamase-producing anaerobes. Recommended treatments include IV clindamycin followed by oral clindamycin or a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination like amoxicillin-clavulanate. Therapy continues until imaging confirms resolution. Metronidazole alone is ineffective since it does not cover microaerophilic streptococci.

Secondary lung abscesses (caused by underlying conditions like malignancy, immunosuppression, or bronchial obstruction) are treated by targeting the identified pathogen and prolonging antibiotic courses based on the patient’s immune status. If no improvement is seen in 7 days, further evaluation is needed to rule out underlying causes.

Large abscesses (>6–8 cm) are less likely to resolve without additional interventions, such as drainage or surgery. Patients who fail antibiotic therapy, especially if they are poor surgical candidates, may require surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. Possible complications of drainage include pleural infection, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.

Note: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled cavities in the lung parenchyma that are seen in respiratory tract infections. They are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children and Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. Below is the chest X-ray showing a pneumatocele.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with tingling and numbness of upper and lower limb extremities. The MRI image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the symptoms of tingling and numbness of both limbs, along with the brain MRI showing ovoid hyperintense demyelinating plaques with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular and callosal surface known as Dawson fingers, characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). 

MS is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the white matter of the central nervous system, causing inflammation, demyelination, axonal damage and neurodegeneration. It predominantly affects women aged 20-40 years and typically follows a relapsing-remitting course, although progressive forms can also occur. The clinical presentation varies depending on the affected location, with common symptoms including paresthesia, visual disturbances (such as optic neuritis), motor weakness and ataxia. Dawson fingers are best visualized on FLAIR imaging and represent demyelination and oligodendrocyte loss, accompanied by astroglial scarring.

The following MRI image depicts Dawson fingers arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was referred by a dentist after she was found to have loss of lamina dura in the tooth. Her radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions with a salt and pepper appearance/pepperpot appearance. The clinical scenario and X-ray features are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism.

Radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges
    • Pathognomonic feature 
    • Seen especially in the second and third fingers
    • Also visualized in the lateral end of the clavicle and symphysis pubis
  • Loss of lamina dura 
    • Thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth
    • Seen as a thin white line
  • Brown’s tumor
    • Expansile lytic lesion generally affecting maxilla/mandible
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull
  • Generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae

A radiograph showing subperiosteal cortical resorption is given below.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ER with left-sided scrotal pain and nausea. It developed suddenly 30 minutes ago while playing football. On examination, the left scrotum is reddish with mild tenderness, and the testis is in horizontal lie. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of sudden scrotal pain while playing is suspicious for testicular torsion. The investigation of choice is doppler ultrasonography. It indicates reduced or absent blood flow to the testes. 

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis due to a 'bell clapper deformity', resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis. It is typically seen in adolescence and usually presents with sudden onset pain and swelling of the scrotum, associated with vomiting. A high-riding, swollen, and tender testis with a tender twisted cord can often be palpated above it, along with an erythematous scrotum and absent cremastric reflex on the affected side. 

A Doppler ultrasound may be taken to assess the blood supply but surgical exploration is still indicated as a clinical decision.  Doppler ultrasound scanning shows absent or decreased intratesticular arterial blood flow compared to the contralateral testis. Doppler studies have improved the ultrasonographic evaluation of testicular torsion with the presence of whirlpool sign within the spermatic cord, which represents the twisted cord and is analogous to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen in ovarian torsion.  

Urgent scrotal exploration is indicated if there is doubt regarding the diagnosis. A transverse scrotal incision is taken and if the testis is viable twisting again is prevented by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, where a middle-aged woman presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids and a barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance, is suggestive of achalasia cardia. 

Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.

On barium swallow, the hallmark bird beak or beak-like appearance is observed, resulting from esophageal dilatation above the constricted LES. However, esophageal manometry is the gold standard diagnostic test. 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with cognitive deficit, involuntary hand and finger movements, and muscle incoordination. The MRI image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the above clinical scenario and coronal T1-weighted MRI findings of bilateral caudate nuclei atrophy with compensatory lateral ventricle dilatation("boxcar ventricles"), the likely diagnosis is Huntington's disease.

This autosomal-dominant neurodegenerative disorder, caused by a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4p, typically affects young adults and is characterised by choreiform movements, psychiatric disturbances, and progressive dementia.

questions.text: The radiograph of a patient on follow-up after hip surgery is given below. This is best described as:

choices.text: Normal total hip replacement implant in situ
Dislocated total hip replacement from cup

questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows a bipolar prosthesis with a dislocated head. The femoral head of the prosthesis is seen to be displaced from the normal acetabulum.

In total hip replacement surgery, both the acetabular cup and the head of the femur are replaced with a prosthesis. The post-op x-ray will show the acetabular cup and head of the femur as seen below.

questions.text: You are performing an ultrasound abdomen and notice the below finding. Which of the following conditions is it associated with?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound abdomen depicts the target sign suggestive of intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Clinically, it presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

A plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign, i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. The target sign of intestinal intussusception, also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign, is a diagnostic feature observed on abdominal ultrasound. This appearance is due to concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by the mucosa and muscularis, and the hypoechoic bands are formed by the submucosa.

Other ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Pseudokidney sign - This is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma, and the mesentery, which is dragged into the intussusception, resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign - A hyperechoic semilunar structure caused by mesenteric fat pulled into the intussceptum.

The below images show USG films depicting the target sign and pseudo-kidney sign respectively.

questions.text: Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure depicted in the image represents myelography.

Myelography is a procedure used to evaluate spinal conditions. X-ray myelography can be used to evaluate the spinal canal in patients with spondylolisthesis. While MRI has largely replaced X-ray myelography it is done when there is a contraindication to MRI (Eg; non-compatible pacemaker, severe claustrophobia).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with a headache and new-onset seizures. There is history of consumption of pork. MRI was taken and given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical presentation, along with the MRI brain showing a cyst with a dot sign (representing an eccentrically placed scolex within a parasitic cyst), is characteristic of neurocysticercosis. 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common form of cysticercosis and is caused by encysted larvae of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium. This CNS infection typically occurs through the consumption of food or water contaminated with human feces containing Taenia eggs or via the ingestion of undercooked pork. It can affect the brain parenchyma, subarachnoid space and ventricles.

Clinically, it presents with seizures and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes), dizziness, ataxia, confusion or signs of meningeal irritation.

Parenchymal neurocysticercosis can be categorised into four stages -vesicular, colloidal vesicular, granular nodular, and nodular calcified. These stages are readily identified on MRI or CT, depending on the lesion's progression. It is characterised by cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement, focal enhancing lesions, nodular calcifications or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Viable parasites appear as cystic lesions with a scolex, often visible on MRI, while calcified, non-viable cysts are more effectively identified on CT. 

Differential diagnoses for ring-enhancing lesions include brain abscess, toxoplasmosis, central nervous system lymphoma, tuberculoma.

Other options: 

Option B: Tuberculomas (parenchymal granulomas) can mostly occur at the junction of white and grey matter. On CT, they appear as small rounded lesions, solid lesions show homogenous enhancement on contrast CT and show ring enhancement when central caseation or liquefaction occurs. MRI brain shows >20mm, conglomerate or lobulated irregular shape, ring-enhancing lesion.  

Option C: Primary CNS lymphoma is more common in immunocompromised individuals, though its incidence in HIV patients has decreased with anti-retroviral therapy. Imaging typically shows single or multiple lesions with contrast enhancement, which is uniform in immunocompetent patients and ring-like those who are immunosupressed. Notably, EBV-associated cases in immunocompetent individuals may show rim enhancement. 

Option D: Brain abscess typically presents as a triad of fever, focal neurological deficits and signs of raised intracranial pressure. It is usually seen with a predisposing condition such as cyanotic heart disease, infected sinuses, middle ear or tooth infection, bacterial meningitis and immunodeficiencies. Common causative organisms include streptococci, gram-negative anaerobic bacilli, enterobacteriaceae, and staphylococcus aureus.

The below MRI shows a ring-enhancing lesion, suggestive of brain abscess.

questions.text: A two-day-old neonate with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium underwent a barium enema study, as shown below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.

The most important sign on barium enema is a sudden change of calibre from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel.

Hirschsprung disease is characterized by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum. This may occur due to the failure of neuroblasts in neural crest cells to migrate into bowel segments or the degeneration of already migrated neuroblasts.  Hence, functional obstruction develops as a result of a spasm in the denervated colon. 

Clinical features typically include failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life, abdominal distension, vomiting, and constipation. Hirschsprung disease may present with enterocolitis, a severe complication that can be life-threatening. There is a notable association between Hirschsprung disease and Down's syndrome.

Water-soluble contrast enema is the initial investigation and diagnostic test of choice. It shows a narrow aganglionic segment, a conical transition zone, and a dilated proximal bowel. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation.

The image below shows dilated ganglionic and contracted aganglionic segments in Hirschsprung disease:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in colour) that indicate fatty tissue. This is suggestive of renal angiomyolipomas.

Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign tumours that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. AMLs predominantly affect the kidneys, though they can occur in other sites such as the liver (a common extra-renal location) and less frequently in the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon. 

Histologically, angiomyolipomas consist of perivascular epitheloid cells with varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells. Patients with AMLs present with flank pain, a palpable mass, hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. Larger tumours increase the risk of complications, such as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which can manifest as sudden-onset abdominal or flank pain, along with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and hypotension.

Everolimus is used for the treatment of angiomyolipomas. Treatment should be considered for asymptomatic, growing AMLs measuring >3 cm in diameter. Angiomyolipomas do not normally require surgery unless life-threatening bleeding is present.

Other options:

Renal cyst is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions need evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification is used for renal cysts. Cysts appear as hypodense lesions (greyish) with a thin wall, with or without septations.

CT image showing a simple renal cyst:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumour of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the ER with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

It occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The apex of a sigmoid volvulus usually lies high on the left side. The apex of a caecal volvulus may lie on the right side or extend to the left upper quadrant. The swirl sign in with sigmoid volvulus is located at the level of the pelvic brim while the swirl in cecal volvulus is located in the right lower quadrant. 

Other options: 

 Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure, leading to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. A CT scan is more accurate for differentiating functional from mechanical obstruction. The image given below is an X-ray of the paralytic ileus showing gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels. 

Differences between the small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

 

Option B: Colonic diverticula are almost all false diverticula, i.e., mucosa herniating through a defect in the muscularis layer, typically covered by overlying serosa (where present). The given barium enema study shows a saw-tooth appearance due to barium-filled outpouchings, suggestive of colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: Identify the vessel marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the MR angiography of cerebral circulation. The structure marked is the anterior cerebral artery which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A young soccer player presents with complaints of pain in his right shoulder. He fell while alternating from jumping jacks to push-ups during a warm-up drill. His shoulder's radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the light bulb sign in the X-ray is suggestive of a posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

It occurs most commonly during a convulsion, or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand. 

There is internal rotation of humeral head which causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. 

Radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • Light bulb sign - Shape of humeral head appears like that of an electric bulb
  • Rim sign - Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm
  • Vacant glenoid sign - Glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it
  • Trough sign - Vertical line seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum

questions.text: Which of the following types of microcalcification poses the maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Cluster microcalcification poses the greatest risk of indicating a malignancy and Diffuse microcalcification poses the least.

Related Pearl: Types of microcalcification indicating malignancy

In decreasing order of risk of malignancy-

  • Cluster microcalcification (maximum risk)
  • Linear microcalcification
  • Segmental microcalcification
  • Diffuse microcalcification (minimum risk)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has been experiencing intermittent visual disturbances and episodes of difficulty walking over the past few months. Neurological examination reveals spasticity in the lower limbs and hyperreflexia. T2W MRI of the brain shows periventricular ovoid hyperintense lesions oriented perpendicular to lateral ventricles. Which of the radiological findings is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and T2W MRI of the brain showing periventricular ovoid hyperintense lesions oriented perpendicular to lateral ventricles, called Dawson's fingers, are characteristic of multiple sclerosis. 

Multiple sclerosis(MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms.

It is commonly associated with paresthesia (tingling sensations), hypesthesia (numbness), optic neuritis, unilateral/ bilateral, limb weakness - spastic paralysis, Babinski's sign positive and bladder dysfunction. Optic neuritis (ON) presents as diminished visual acuity or decreased colour perception (desaturation) in the central field of vision.

MRI is used for making the diagnosis of MS due to its high sensitivity. The diagnosis of MS requires demonstrating that the lesions are disseminated in space (involving multiple areas of the brain) and in time (multiple episodes over a period of time).

The MRI below demonstrates Dawson's fingers, the demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location).

Other options:

Option A: A "puff of smoke appearance", derived from the Japanese term Moyamoya, is a characteristic finding on cerebral X-ray angiography in patients with Moyamoya disease. This rare, non-inflammatory, progressive, occlusive disease involves large intracranial arteries exhibiting bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya is characterised by ischemic manifestations, and adult moyamoya by hemorrhagic manifestations.

The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease.

As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion, seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography as shown below: 

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal-recessive disease resulting from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A, causing central and peripheral demyelination, ataxia, and dementia.

Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2 hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent the sparing of the perivascular white matter. This results in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U-fibers are spared. The below MRI shows tigroid pattern: 

Option D: Progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by atrophy of structures at the midbrain-diencephalic junction (e.g., superior colliculi, red nuclei, subthalamic nuclei, and globus pallidus) and cerebellum (dentate nuclei), and mild cortical atrophy. MRI shows a hummingbird sign (atrophy of midbrain structures with a relatively intact pons region).

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above CT image is the left ventricle. 

Transverse CT images are to be observed from the foot end of the supine patient, as if we are sitting at the patient's feet. So the right-hand side of the observer corresponds to the left-hand side in the CT.

questions.text: A young male presents with pain in his right shoulder. He slipped during his treadmill workout and tried to hold on to the side rails. The x-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient who developed pain in his shoulder after forced abduction of his shoulder after a fall. The x-ray shows the head of the humerus is below the glenoid and the shaft in the abducted position. This is suggestive of an inferior shoulder dislocation, also known as luxatio erecta. 

It is rare and occurs when the arm is forcefully pulled up when in full abduction (hyper-abduction force) due to high-energy trauma. The patient will present with the arm locked in almost full abduction.

questions.text: A thin, 34-year-old male, presents with sharp pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph clearly depicts the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space.

  • The right hemithorax shows blackening (depicts area of low density) due to the presence of air.
  • The visceral pleural line has separated from the chest wall by a transradiant zone devoid of vessels.
  • The collapsed lung can be seen with a clear border.
  • There is a mediastinal shift to the left side (contralateral), which is typically seen with cases of tension pneumothorax. 

All the above features are suggestive of pneumothorax.

Note: Pleural effusions signify the presence of fluid accumulation in the pleural space. The fluid may have varying degrees of mobility depending on the nature of effusion (free-flowing or loculated).

While a small amount of free fluid is usually hard to detect on an erect PA chest x-ray, a significant pleural effusion (200-500 mL) is represented by obscured lateral and posterior costophrenic angles and the hemidiaphragm affected. Subsequently, homogenous opacification of the lower lung field develops, associated with concave superior margin relative to the lung. This margin is higher laterally than medially. 

A massive pleural effusion cause dense opacification usually associated with a contralteral mediastinal shift. 

Here is an image of a left-sided pleural effusion representing the homogenous opacification of the left lower and middle lung fields. There is associated blunting of the left sided costophrenic angle. The superior border of the effusion is concave and is higher laterally than medially.

questions.text: The given finding is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given image shows short 4th metacarpal. This is seen in the following conditions:

  • Pseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
  • Turner’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic
  • Post infection

questions.text: Bilateral posterior iliac horns shown below are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")  are characteristic of nail-patella syndrome. They are seen due to exostoses arising from the posterior aspect of the iliac bones.

Nail-patella syndrome: Also known as Fong disease or osteo-onychodysostosis. It may also be referred to as Österreicher-Turner syndrome or Turner-Kieser syndrome.

It is a rare autosomal dominant condition which results from symmetrical mesodermal and ectodermal abnormalities. The key feature is absent/hypoplastic nails from birth. Individuals may have flexion contractures and recurrent knee dislocations.

Diagnostic radiographic findings include:

  • Absent/hypoplastic patellae (with a tendency of recurrent dislocation)
  • Hypoplasia of the radial head or capitulum (leading to subluxation/dislocation)
  • Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")
  • Protuberant anterior iliac spines

questions.text: What is the SI unit for absorbed radiation?
questions.solution:
The SI unit of absorbed radiation is Gray, and the common unit is RAD.

1 Gray = 100 RAD = 1 J/Kg

Quantity measured

Old Unit

(conventional)

New Unit

(SI unit)
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy)
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv)

questions.text: The image given below is a characteristic finding of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a teardrop bladder (pear-shaped bladder) characteristically seen in pelvic hematoma. It is also seen in pelvic lipomatosis,  pelvic abscess, bilateral pelvic lymphadenopathy, and intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

A pear-shaped (or teardrop-shaped) bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed to resemble a pear. The pear may be inverted or upright, depending on how the excess pelvic tissue compresses the bladder.

Other important radiological appearances in urogenital system:

  • Fir tree/pine tree/Christmas tree bladder: Neurogenic bladder
  • Sun-burst appearance of the bladder: Extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • Thimble bladder: Tubercular cystitis
  • Paint-brush appearance: Medullary sponge kidney
  • Drooping flower appearance: Ectopic ureter
  • Rim sign/crescent sign: Hydronephrosis
  • Bilateral spider leg deformity: Polycystic kidney disease.
  • Flower vase curves of the ureter: Horseshoe kidney.
  • Saw-toothed or cock screw appearance of ureter: Tubercular ureteritis

questions.text: Corduroy sign in a sagittal CT of the spine is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Corduroy sign in a sagittal/coronal CT of the spine is suggestive of a vertebral hemangioma.

It occurs due to the replacement of the normal cancellous bone by thickened vertical trabeculae surrounded by fat marrow or vascular lacunae in intraosseous haemangiomas, mimicking the appearance of corduroy cloth.

The same pathology in an axial section will give a polka-dot appearance as shown below.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male presented with progressive gait disturbance and impaired vision. T2 weighted MRI is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above T2 weighted MRI shows an increased signal of the peritrigonal regions extending across the splenium of the corpus callosum, which is characteristic of the X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy.

The condition is usually seen in boys between 5 - 10 years of age. It is the most common leukodystrophy of children

It is caused due to the inflammatory demyelination of the deep white matter involving the splenium and peritrigonal white matter and progressing to the corticospinal tracts and visual and auditory pathways. The inflammation is caused due to the accumulation of VLCFA.

As a result the children present with learning difficulties, behavioral problems, progressive disturbance in gait and impaired vision.

Lorenzo’s oil may delay disease progression

Radiological features:

On MRI, there is signal abnormality (Increased signal on T2WI and low signal on T1WI) posteriorly, involving the peritrigonal region and extending to the splenium. Marginal enhancement is usually seen at the leading edge due to the active inflammation.

Imaging findings of other options:

The pattern of signal abnormality on MRI of various demyelinating diseases is depicted in the image below:

questions.text: Abdominal USG in a 50-year-old male with right upper quadrant abdominal pain revealed the comet tail sign. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and comet-tail sign on USG is seen in adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder.

Adenomyomatous hyperplasia of the gall bladder is also known as cholecystitis glandularis proliferans. It is characterized by gall bladder wall thickening due to epithelial and smooth muscle hyperplasia along with cystic epithelial invagination into the wall, referred to as Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. The most common location is in the fundus of the gall bladder and the sinuses often contain stones. 

On USG, the characteristic findings are a thickened gallbladder wall showing bright echoes arising from the cystic spaces with ‘comet-tail’ ring-down artefacts, as seen in the image below. The comet-tail artefact is caused by the cholesterol crystals trapped within the Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses, causing reverberation (large number of reflected waves).

questions.text:
Which of the following are contraindications of MRI?
  1. Metallic foreign body in the eye
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Cardiac pacemaker
  4. Renal failure
  5. Claustrophobia
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in patients with metallic foreign bodies in the eye, cardiac pacemakers, and claustrophobia.

Contraindications of MRI include:

  • Cardiac pacemakers 
  • Aneurysmal metallic clips
  • Metallic foreign body
  • Cochlear implant
  • Allergy to gadolinium (in contrast MRI)
  • Claustrophobia (relative contraindication)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about conditions required for acute radiation syndrome?

choices.text: Radiation dose must be large i.e greater than 70 rads.
The dose must be mostly internal.
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects.
The dose must have been delivered in a short time.

questions.solution:
Acute radiation syndrome after deposition of radioactive materials inside the body is extremely rare. The dose must be external.

Acute radiation syndrome, also called radiation toxicity or radiation sickness, is an acute illness caused by irradiation of the entire body by a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. The major cause of this syndrome is the depletion of immature parenchymal stem cells in specific tissues.

Stages of Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

The prodromal phase: This phase is marked by non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.

Latent phase: The patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.

Manifest illness phase: Symptoms depend the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.

Recovery phase or Death: The recovery phase is seen after the manifest stage when the patient recovers from the acute exposure. The time taken for recovery depends on the severity of the injury and the organ system affected. 

Syndrome    Dose Prodromal Stage  Latent Stage Manifest Illness Stage Recovery/Death
Hematopoietic (Bone marrow)  >0.7 Gy (>70 rads) (mild symptoms may occur at doses as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
  • Onset occurs 1 hour to 2 days after exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to days.  
  • Stem cells in bone marrow are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.
  • Stage lasts 1 to 6 weeks. 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, fever, and malaise.
  • Drop in all blood cell counts occurs for several weeks.
  • Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage.
  • Survival decreases with increasing dose.
  • Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure.  

 

  • In most cases, bone marrow cells will begin to repopulate the marrow.
  • There should be full recovery for a large percentage of individuals from a few weeks up to two years after exposure.
  • Death may occur in some individuals at 1.2 Gy (120 rads).
  • The LD50/60 is about 2.5 to 5 Gy (250 to 500 rads). 
GIT >10 Gy (>1000 rads) (some symptoms may occur at doses as low as 6 Gy or 600 rads)

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, severe nausea, vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea.
  • Onset occurs within a few hours after exposure.
  • Stage lasts about 2 days.
  • Stem cells in bone marrow and cells lining GI tract are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.
  • Stage lasts less than 1 week.

 

  • Symptoms are malaise, anorexia, severe diarrhea, fever, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death is due to infection, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death occurs within 2 weeks of exposure.
 The LD100 is about 10 Gy (1000 rads).
CVS/CNS >50 Gy (>5000 rads) (some symptoms may occur at doses as low as 20 Gy or 2000 rads)

 

  • Symptoms are extreme nervousness and confusion; severe nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea; loss of consciousness; and burning sensations of the skin.
  • Onset occurs within minutes of exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to hours.
  • Patient may return to partial functionality.
  • Stage may last for hours but often is less.

 

  • Symptoms are return of watery diarrhea, convulsions, and coma.
  • Onset occurs 5 to 6 hours after exposure.
  • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure.
 No recovery is expected.

questions.text: What is the CT number of air?
questions.solution:
CT number of air is −1000 HU.

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalisation, and water is assigned 0 HU and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centered around 0 HU
    • Lungs = -1000 HU
    •  
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU

questions.text: Radiograph of a child with history of delayed walking showed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis with a widening of joint spaces. The radiological features are characteristic of active rickets. 

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with 3 months of amenorrhea. She was found to have abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG.  The USG shows the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario and ultrasound image showing a characteristic pattern known as a bunch of grapes/ honeycombed uterus/ snow-storm appearance, the most probable diagnosis is a hydatidiform mole.

Molar pregnancy or hydatidiform mole results from abnormal chromosomal fertilization. It results in trophoblastic proliferation and villous stromal edema forming an immature placenta. It includes the benign complete hydatidiform mole (46XX) and partial hydatidiform mole (69 XXX or 69 XXY). An invasive mole with malignant potential may also occur.

The previous history of molar pregnancy and extremes of reproductive age are the high-risk factors.

Clinically, the female presents with 1-2 months of amenorrhea followed by vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The uterus size exceeds that of the corresponding gestational age. Serum β-hCG levels are raised above those expected for gestational age. 

In a complete mole, the ultrasound imaging shows a uterine mass made of anechoic cystic masses without a fetus or amniotic sac filling the endometrial cavity surrounded by normal myometrium. This is described as a “snowstorm” appearance.

In a partial mole, thick, multicystic placenta with minimal hydatidiform changes and some fetal tissues may be seen. A thin septum may be found within the gestational sac.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with headache for the past 4 months, she was treated with radiotherapy for vestibular schwannoma 2 year back. What is the probable diagnosis we can arrive from the contrast MRI shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

The well-defined, hyper intense and homogeneously enhanced mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially (i.e., outside the brain parenchyma). Being non-glial in origin they arise from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, and thus can occur anywhere meninges are found.

Meningomas are associated with:

  • Female predominance (some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors).
  • Genetic preponderance: Genetic mutations associated with meningioma are NF-2 and MEN1 mutations.
  • Ionizing radiation

Useful descriptive signs on MRI are:

  • CSF vascular cleft sign helps to establish that mass to be extra-axial. There is a cleft between tumor and normal brain parenchyma.
  • Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based.
  • Sunburst or spoke wheel appearance of the vessels.

questions.text: The contrast media used in the study depicted below is contraindicated in all the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given image is a contrast radiograph of a barium meal. Barium-based contrast media can be used in the case of bowel strictures, but only in small amounts.

Barium-based contrast media:

  • They are preferred for the study of the gastrointestinal tract as they is very poorly soluble and are not absorbed during passage through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • They can cause granulomas and, rarely, fatal reactions on leaking into the mediastinum or peritoneal cavity. Therefore, they are contraindicated when:
    • the integrity of the gut wall is compromised, e.g. suspected aspiration, a fistula between esophagus and lungs, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, and/or
    • there is a history of allergic reactions to barium products.
  • They are used with caution in case of bowel strictures and extensive colitis.
  • Complications: Leakage into the vasculature, worsening of ulcerative colitis inflammation

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with a port-wine nevus on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. On radiological examination, the given appearance of the skull is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image of the skull showing tram track sign (gyriform calcification in a curvilinear pattern), along with the history of port-wine nevus and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas point to a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome is characterized by a port-wine nevus (along the course of the trigeminal nerve) on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. It is a congenital syndrome.

There is an increased risk of seizures and intracranial calcifications in the child before 2 years of age. There may be associated hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay. The ocular findings commonly associated are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, visual field defects, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Images show port-wine stain associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.


Features of MRI brain include

  • Pial angioma is seen as a diffuse pial enhancement of variable thickness.
  • Enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilatation of transparenchymal veins that communicate between the superficial and deep cerebral venous systems 

MRI and CT show intracranial calcification respectively. The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cerebral cortex.


Other options:

Option A: Moya-moya disease is characterized by dilatation of collateral vessels resulting from stenosis of the internal carotid artery appearing as puff of smoke pattern on angiography.

Option C: Von Hippel Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant multiorgan disorder characterized by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas with an increased risk of developing renal cell carcinomas.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis is a multi-system neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomyolipomas, cysts in kidneys, multiple hamartomas, giant cell astrocytomas, and cortical tubers.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a Barium meal. (The condition depicted is trichobezoar which shows a filling defect in a barium meal X-ray)

Barium is used as a contrast for GI imaging.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheo esophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used
  • Perforation peritonitis: Gastrograffin-Ionic water soluble agent is used

Procedures: For Single contrast films barium alone is used. Double contrast films requires air and barium which is better for small mucosal lesion.

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus)
  • Ba meal- 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum)
  • Ba meal follow through -50% BaSO4 (for small bowel)
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel)

Enteroclysis - gastrointestinal technique designed to provide improved evaluation of the small bowel from jejunum to ileocecal junction. It is done by intubating the jejunum and instillation of the contrast material through the tube.

The conventional fluoroscopic technique is not widely used since it is somewhat invasive, time and labour intensive, and not particularly pleasant for the patient. Modifications of the tradition technique may involve CT or MRI. It is indicated for examination of mucosal detail of the small intestine and improved evaluation of small bowel tumours or inflammatory disease.

questions.text: What is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image above represents the Bragg-peak effect of a proton.

The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy, therefore, allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. 

Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon whereby increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2 (as Hb-bound, carbamino Hb; or as HCO3-), thereby increasing the CO2 partial pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following imaging modalities uses the harmonic imaging technique?
questions.solution:
Harmonic imaging is a technique used in sonography.

In tissue harmonic imaging sonography, higher harmonic frequencies generated by the propagation of the ultrasound beam through tissue are used to produce the sonogram. They result in better images.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, and the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images. 

Other options: 

Option A: In T1 weighted images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Option C: FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

Option D: STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of low-grade fever and progressive chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed the following. Considering the symptoms and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow, called the money bag appearance. Considering the above symptoms and the chest X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is pericardial effusion. 

The investigation of choice is echocardiography. However, the following x-ray findings are also characteristic for pericardial effusion:

  • AP view - money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart
  • Lateral view - Oreo cookie sign (fluid is seen between two layers of fat)

In the following image, pericardial fluid (yellow asterisk) outlined by paracardial fat (blue arrows) and epicardial fat (orange arrows) is called the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. He had arrived from an international trip three days ago. A chest x-ray was done. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, chest pain and dyspnea after air travel most likely points to a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Westermark sign is seen in the given chest x-ray.

It is defined by a hyper-lucent area with decreased vascularity due to reduced blood supply to the involved part of the lung.

Even though characteristic signs are seen on chest x-ray, it is neither sensitive nor specific for pulmonary embolism. CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the investigation of choice in pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Kerley A lines?

choices.text: Radiate from the hilum of lungs
Runs perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it
Short lines which do not reach the pleura

questions.solution:
Kerley A lines radiate from the hilum of the lungs.

Kerley lines are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. 

This may be because of lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. They usually occur when pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines:  

  • Kerley A lines:
    • Thin, oblique lines(2-6cm long and thickness under 1mm), radiating from the hilum to the upper lobes. 
    • HRCT is the most effective imaging technique to identify these lines. 
  • Kerley B lines:
    • Thin, horizontal lines (1-2 cm long), seen at the lung periphery, usually near the bases. 
    • Run perpendicular to the pleural surface and reach it, representing thickened subpleural interlobular septa.
  • Kerley C lines :
    • Short, irregular lines with a spider web-like appearance. 
    • Unlike Kerley B and D lines, they do not extend to the pleura; unlike Kerley A lines, they do not radiate outward from the hila.
  • Kerley D lines - the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap

The image below depicts the Kerley B line, perpendicular to the pleural surface:

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the leg. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and radiograph showing onion peel type of periosteal reaction point towards a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant tumor that occurs more frequently in males, typically between 10 and 20 years of age, and has a diaphyseal long-bone location. The femur is the most common long-bone site, followed by the tibia, humerus, and fibula. Ewing’s sarcoma is believed to arise from mesenchymal stem cells in the bone marrow.

Other options: 

Option A: Osteosarcoma has a periosteal reaction characterised as Codman triangle. It can also be seen in Ewing’s sarcoma.

Option C: Giant cell tumor has a characteristic soap bubble appearance.

Option D: Unicameral bone cyst has a pathognomonic fallen fragment sign.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: What does the Hounsfield unit depend on?
questions.solution:
Hounsfield unit (HU) depends on the linear attenuation co-efficient.

Attenuation is the reduction of the intensity of an X-ray beam as it traverses matter. HU is used to measure the X-ray attenuation values in CT scanning, thus quantifying the radiodensity of the tissue. 

Tissues Hounsfield unit
Cortical bone

+1000 HU (Bright white)
Solid soft tissue

+40 to +80 HU (sometimes upto +300) 
Acute hemorrhage +45 to +65 HU 
Water 0 HU (Grey) 
Fat -100 HU 
Lungs -950 to -700 HU
Air -1000 HU (Jet black)

The Hounsfield scale, named after Sir Godfrey Hounsfield invented CT in the year 1972 and was awarded Nobel Prize for Medicine in the year 1979.

questions.text: An oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases in a 49-year-old woman with breast cancer.  The radioactive isotope of which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation. 

Given below is a bone scan demonstrating bony metastasis in the pelvis.

Other options:

Phosphorous (P-32) and Iridium (Ir-192) are used in radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is an iso-osmolar contrast media?
questions.solution:
Iodixanol has an osmolarity of 300 mOsm which is iso-osmolar to plasma. It is a non-ionic dimer with iodine:particle ratio of 6:1.

Contrast containing iodine is used in CT, IVP, and angiography. Since all these imaging modalities are based on X-rays, iodine is used as it is radio-opaque. In contrast medium, iodine provides radio-opacity and the other elements act as carriers of iodine. These carriers increase the solubility and decrease the toxicity of iodine.
